Dans le souci de conserver leur clientèle  en leur offrant  des services de qualité  et en mettant à leur disposition des produits en quantité, le groupe Ambé alako a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Les deux premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  des cartons  de poissons fumés, des sacs de manioc, de patate et d’igname. Elles s’approvisionnent en poissons à Mopti, et en tubercules à partir de Sikasso. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Ambé Alako are all married and average 28 years of age and 3 children each. They live in large traditional extended families in the Médina Koura district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know one another by neighborhood ties, and their main work involves selling smoked fish, tubers, and vegetables.

Wanting to retain their customers by offering them quality services and by making large quantities of goods available to them, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The first two loans have been repaid.

The women plan to use this loan to buy boxes of smoked fish and sacks of cassava, potatoes, and yams. Supplies of fish are gotten in Mopti, and the tubers are gotten from Sikasso.

They each hope to realize an average profit of 110,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in their work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy smoked fish and tubers

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia sells fish and snails. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more fish to sell. She sells fish wholesale and retail to her customers. She is 50 years old and married with 2 children. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Balimaya (La Parenté) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Balimaya  sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier médina Koura  de la  ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens  de voisinage et pour la pratique de la même activité. Elles font activité principale la confection de bogolan (pagne orné avec du banco très joli qu’elles ont appris   avec les parents)  et comme activité secondaire la fabrication de l’encens. 
Pour donner satisfaction à sa clientèle riche et variée qui augmente de jour au jour, le groupe Balimaya a décidé d’intégrer   l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son septième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés . 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  des tissus en  cotonnade en grande quantité et des ingrédients pour l’encens. Elles s’approvisionnent en tissus avec les tisserands de Koutiala et les ingrédients de l’encens sont achetés dans les boutiques de vente de produits cosmétiques (parfums et autres).Les pagnes     en cotonnade confectionnés en bogolan sont vendus en détail au comptant au marché et dans les foires aussi bien que l’encens. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen d 115 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
 Elles ont pour ambition d’agrandir leurs activités et participer à  des foires internationales.
texts.en:
The five women of the group Balimaya are all married and average 42 years of age and 5 children each. They live in large traditional extended families in the Médina Koura district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know one another by neighborhood ties, and they do the same work, primarily making bogolan (very pretty mud-cloth that they learned to make from their parents). Secondarily, they make incense.

To satisfy their rich and varied customer base, which increases from day to day, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their seventh solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The women plan to use this loan to buy sizable quantities of cotton cloth and some ingredients for incense. Supplies of cloth are gotten from weavers of Koutiala, and the ingredients for incense are purchased from shops selling cosmetics (perfumes and other items). The lengths of cotton cloths are made into the bogolan and then sold retail, as are the incense, in cash transactions at the marketplace and at fairs.

The women each hope to realize an average profit of 115,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to pay the loan interest, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in their work. Their ambition is to expand their businesses and to participate in international fairs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cotton cloth and ingredients for incense

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 30 years old, and she is married with 2 children. She is a LAPO client. She sells snails, fish, and dry pepper. She loves this business because she makes a lot of profits. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more snails to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more snails to sell

loans.name: Tièssiri  3 (Soyons Courageux) Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au premier quartier  de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente  de bois de chauffe  et la restauration. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. 
Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son cinquième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour  constituer un stock important de bois de chauffe, acheter  des sacs de haricot et des bidons d’huile alimentaires. Le bois de chauffe est vendu  en détail, au comptant à la maison. Quant au haricot il est vendu après cuisson, la nuit au carrefour avec de l’huile.
 Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 140 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en faisant le stockage de  céréales toutes qualités confondues et être grossiste dans la vente du bois de chauffe.
texts.en:
The six women of the Tiessiri group are all married, are on average 30 years old with 5 children, and live in large traditional extended families in the first district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They know each other as neighbours and as relatives. They all engage in almost the same type of businesses: firewood sales and food preparation. They are highly sought after in this work. In the framework of improving the quality of their services and enlarging the size of their businesses, the members of the Confiance group decided to work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are seeking their fifth solidarity (group) loan. All of their previous loans were repaid properly. They intend to use this loan to create a sizable stock of firewood and to buy bags of beans and cans of cooking oil. The firewood is sold at retail in cash at their homes. As for the beans, they are sold after cooking at night at the crossroads with the oil. They each hope to earn an average profit of 140,000 FCFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to repay the loan and meet the needs of their extended families, with the rest being invested in their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their business by stocking cereals of all types together and becoming wholesalers of firewood.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, cooking oil, and beans

loans.name: Djiguiya (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Djiguiya sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 4 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Dar Salam 2 de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage.
Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente  de friperie (articles usagers habits et chaussures). Elles sont très sollicitées dans ce domaine. 
Afin de palier la rupture de stocks qui fait l’objet de  baisse de clientèle, le groupe Djiguiya a trouvé la solution de son problème en intégrant l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de friperie en gros et une quantité importante de chaussures d’occasion à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Ces habits et chaussures d’occasion  sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de Koutiala et  en ambulant dans les quartiers de la ville. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 55 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus telle que la vente de sacs de friperie.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Djiguiya are all married and on average 34 years old with 4 children, and live in large traditional extended families in the Dar Salam 2 district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met each other as neighbours. They are all engaged in almost the same business selling second-hand clothing (used clothes and shoes). They are highly sought after in this regard. In order to overcome the stock shortages which cause a decrease in their clientele, the Djiguiya group found the solution to their problem by joining the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are seeking their first solidarity (group) loan. They intend to use this loan to buy bales of used clothing in bulk and a sizable quantity of second-hand shoes in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). These second-hand clothes and shoes are sold at retail, in cash and on credit, at the market in Koutiala and door-to-door in the city's districts. They each hope to realize an average profit of 55,000 FCFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to repay the loan and to meet the needs of their extended families, with the rest being invested in their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their business by taking up other revenue-generating activities such as the sale of second-hand bags.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothing and shoes

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Clara is 56 years old and married with 8 children. She is a tailor and she also sells clothes and tailoring materials. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more clothes and tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 56-year-old married man with five children, living in Borj Al Barajneh, in the Beirut suburbs. He has owned a taxi for the past 15 years. His services cover Beirut and the suburban areas. Today, Ahmad is requesting a loan of $1,000 to perform maintenance on his taxi.

loans.use: Perform maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Unidos Podemos 1 Group

texts.en:
Maria M. is the group 1 coordinator for the Unidos Podemos (United we Can) Bank of Hope from El Seybo. Maria and her group will be taking out their 7th loan from Esperanza International. Maria has 2 children ages 17 and 11. Her goal is to make her business grow in order to support her family. She finds that her biggest challenge is to remain in good standing with her financial commitments. 

Maria raises pigs for resale. She is now expanding into raising chickens, since they are cheaper to raise and in more demand. This way she can raise an animal in a short time and sell it quickly. She hopes one day that the profits that she makes from raising animals in her backyard and sells in her community market, will be enough to buy a farm and supply meat on a larger scale. 

Thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: purchase pigs and chickens for resale

loans.name: Sylvana

texts.en: Sylvana is a 30-year-old married woman with four children and she lives in the Katarmaya municipality in Mount Lebanon Governate.  She runs a bakery that she first opened in 1998.  Her last micro loan with Ameen was taken to increase her bakery's inventory.  Today, Sylvana wants to borrow $1,200 to purchase additional flour for the bakery.

loans.use: Buy flour inventory

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 40-year-old man living in the village of Chhim in Mount Lebanon Governate.  He owns a linen shop which serves his village and the surrounding villages.  He has already received several micro loans from Ameen to improve his business. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 to be used to buy inventory at a very good price.

loans.use: Buy more inventory

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 40-year-old widower with four children, living in the Katarmaya municipality of Mount Lebanon Governate.  He has been in construction work for more than 23 years.  He is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy wood to improve the quality of his construction projects.

loans.use: Buy wood

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou G. is 49 years old, a mother of five, and married to Wilfredo, 50 years old, who is a farmer.  

Her five children include Wilma - 28 years old, Wendelyn – 25 years old, Wilfredo G. Jr. - 23 years old.  They are all college graduates currently working in Manila as teachers.  Her other two children are still studying in high school. They are William - 20 years old, and Willinda -16 years old. 

The village where her family lives is a poor village at the moment, and quite distant from the market proper of Tumauini. 

Marilou has an agricultural machine for rice and corn, commonly called a thresher, in their village which is operated by her husband and some paid laborers, especially during harvest season.  Their thresher helped a lot to other farmers in their village because with the machine, they were able to minimize time and it made harvesting easier for them.  Moreover, they were able to employ some farm laborers during the peak season of harvest. 

But still, their income is not enough to sustain the needs of the family because they only earn money during the harvest season.  So, Marilou wants to avail a loan amounting to Php 6,000 to start a new business in meat vending and other kinds of products in their village.  She hopes it will be approved, and that the business will last long for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To start a new business

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is happily married to Alexander N. who is a farmer and also a motorcycle driver.  They are blessed with two children: Harley Dave, 9 years old and a grade four student, and Hedel Wyze, 3 years old.  Her eldest son lives with her grandmother in La Union and is presently studying there to accompany the elderly lady since she has no other companion.  Her family lives in a small community in Barangay Sto. Tomas Alicia, Isabela. 

For almost five years, the community store has been their source of survival, but it still cannot fulfill all their needs and aspirations.  She plans to borrow Php 13,000 as additional capital so that she will be able to set up a livestock (pig) business. 

Wilma hopes to maintain her village store for sustainability so that, in the future, her children will not experience the hardships of life they’ve been through.  Thus, she is sacrificing a lot to send her children to school to finish their studies.

loans.use: To start a livestock business

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie G. runs a hog raising business in her village of Sitio Anguapan.  With the assistance of her husband, Dominador, who is a farmer, she has been able to maintain the business for a year already.  

Elvie is already 34 years old and has been blessed with three children: Rachel - 10 years old, Rebecca - 8 years old, and the youngest child, Ruth - 6 years old who are all in their primary level of education in Barangay Sto. Nińo, 2-3 kilometers away from the town proper.

After raising a pig for 4 months, Elvie then butchers the animal and sells the meat in kilos at retail price.  Elvie has observed that her business strategy is good, so she plans to add at least one or two piglets to raise.  To fulfill this, she needs to borrow PHP6,000. 

Her business helps her a lot in sending her children to school and in providing for their needs at home including financial assistance for their farm.  As such, she really wants to maintain the business for sustainability. 

Elvie is looking forward for the success of her business in the future and, if that happens, she will no longer have problems in sending her children to school, for there will be enough assistance coming from her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more piglets to raise

loans.name: Olympia

texts.en:
Olympia is 55 years old and married to Leonardo who works as a farm tenant.  Her six caring and loving children are: Liwliwa - 34 years old and a high school graduate who works as a domestic helper in Hongkong; Rosemarie - 31 years old and a high school graduate; Joselyn - 30 years old and a college graduate; Rosaldo - 26 years old and a high school undergraduate; Luzviminda - 28 years old and also a high school undergraduate, and Randy - 18 years old.  Most of her children are married and live with their own families already. 

Even at her age, Olympia has not stopped her business of selling vegetables to different villages.  She works hard to generate income to help her husband in meeting their daily needs like food and saving for their health needs.  She earns a weekly income of PHP 900 pesos, which she wisely budgets.

She wishes to sell more vegetables, so she has requested a loan of PHP 4,000 pesos.  She intends to buy vegetables that will not spoil easily.  Olympia also plans to buy a rolling cart were she can put most of her vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and a rolling cart

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita C. lives in Villa Cayaban, Malalinta, San Manuel, Isabela.  She is 40 years old and married to Marcelino, 36 years old, whi is a farmer.  They have two children; both are in their primary level of education and they are: John Kyle - 6 years old, and Jade Karen – 5 years old.

Since farming is their primary source of income, Clarita decided to engage in vegetable vending.  She sells their own crops and harvests in their village.  She can earn a weekly net income of PHP1, 200.  

She wants to contribute more to their financial needs, so she has availed for a loan of PHP4, 000.  She intends to use the loan to increase her merchandise and buy fruits that she will sell.  

Helping one another is what this couple is doing in order to expand their business and save money for the education of their two children.  They want their children to finish their studies because education is the only possession they can give them for the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise and fruits to sell

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida lives in the village of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela.  She is 49 years old and married to Leonard.  Their three children are Ereneo - 26 years old and studying in his third year college, Gilbert - 20 years old who has finished his first year high school and is now a construction worker, and Leonardo D. Jr. - 12 years old and studying in his 1st year of high school in the nearby public school. 

Leonida has a passenger motorcycle business in their village; it is operated daily by her husband.  The money that they earn is used to finance their children’s education and their family's daily needs including monthly bills of electricity and water.  

Their motorcycle transport business is being amortized monthly; thus, their income from its daily operation is just enough.  

Leonida is looking forward to her request for a loan of PHP5, 000 being granted so they will have money to use for motorcycle maintenance since, at the moment, it always malfunctions due to its needs for some spare parts and repair.  

Their motorcycle transport is their only means of satisfying their family's needs; thus, Leonida prays for the financial support to their business.

loans.use: Motorcycle Maintenance

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
A comfortable life is what Helen wants for her children.  Therefore, she is striving to attain her goals by working patiently and diligently.  She is 33 years old and married to Carlito, who is working as a farmer.  They are blessed with two children named Hannah - 8 years old, and Carl - 1 year old.  Helen is always looking forward to the future of her children.  At present, they live blissfully in Manano, Mallig, Isabela. 

Helen is operating a “talipapa”, the common name for a vending stall of meat, fish, vegetables and some pieces of fruit.  The business is located in front of their house.  She decided to engage herself in this line of business to support her husband in providing for the needs for their family, especially for their children’s education. 

Helen is earning a net income of 700 pesos per week, which maintains her vending as a major source of income.  To run her business better, Helen wants to borrow a loan amounting to PHP4, 000, which will be used in purchasing other kinds of vegetables that are nutritious and are not easily spoiled.  Helen hopes to set up a business stall in the market.  However, due to lack of financial support, she just patiently operates in their village.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables to sell

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola L. is from the village of Sitio Anguapan located in Barangay Sto Nińo Tumauini, Isabela - a small village where farming is the main source of income for most people.  

She is 48 years of age and married to Wilfredo, who is 46 years old and works as a simple farmer in the village.  They are blessed with three children named Jerome -16 years old and in his fourth year of high school, Jolibeth -14 years old and in her third year of high school, and the youngest is Carol - only 3 years old.  Viola is trying her best to send her children to school until college with the simple business she maintains.   

Viola has been raising goats in their village for almost four years already.  She is fond of doing the business since it doesn’t require lots of capital to maintain.  She just brings them to grasslands near their house and cuddles her youngest daughter while they are pasturing. 

She wishes to avail a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 to help her husband provide for the needs of their family by means of engaging in another business.  She said that it will be of great assistance to her family if her loan is approved, especially for her children who are currently studying.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly P. is 45 years old and married to Alejandro who is a driver.  They have 6 children named Arnold, Christina, Anthony, Rizalyn, Arnel and Cedrick.  Her three younger children are still studying in high school and elementary levels.  Nelly hopes that they will be able to keep them in school and allow them to finish their studies despite the prevailing crisis they are suffering. 

Through their motorcycle transport business, Nelly and her husband have been able to overcome starvation and still manage to send their children to school.  They are thankful that their village has easy access to transportation, markets and different schools, since it is situated in the town proper of ILagan. 

She wishes to avail a loan amounting to Php4,000 pesos so that she will able to help her husband with their financial needs in order to maintain their motorcycle transport and somehow to start up a new business of pig raising.

Nelly says that God is good and in all circumstances of life, and that her family will be able to surpass and survive difficulties through deep faith in God.

loans.use: Motorcycle Maintenance

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda C. lives in the village of Calamagui 1st, Ilagan.  She is 32 years old and married to Christopher, 31 years old and working as OFW abroad.  They are blessed with three children named John Mark - 10 years old, Mark Clart - 8 years old, and Ian - 7 years old.  All of them are elementary school students.  The good relationships in their family inspire Imelda to strive for a better life. 

Imelda generates income for her family by means of a direct selling business.  She purchases AVON products and then offers them to her friends and neighbors in their village.  She walks and visits every house of her customers' to encourage them to buy her products.  However, due to lack of capital, Imelda is hoping to avail a loan amounting to PHP6, 000 as additional capital for her business. 

Imelda works hard for her family.  She also looks for other types of selling businesses as alternatives to her AVON business.

Moreover, Imelda believes that God is always present to look over their needs.  She learned to be humble to those who used to criticize her because she knows that she’ll be exalted in heaven with God.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Hay Dee

texts.en:
Hay Dee P. is a resident of Calamagui 1st village. She is 35 years old and married to Jojit, 40 years old, a driver in their village. They have been blessed with 3 children namely: Analiza - 15 years old, studying third year high school; Judy - 12 years old, studying first year high school; and John Mark - 5 years old. The family has good relationships and respect their elders.

Hay Dee manages a buy and sell business of charcoal in their village. She wishes to receive a loan in the amount of PHP6,000 as additional capital for her business. Hay Dee needs to work hard and strives to increase her daily income, so she can help her husband with their motorcycle transport monthly amortization, and send their children to school. She aims for a successful business and hopes for its development. Doing her best towards the development of her business is a great challenge for her. She wants to become productive in her business undertakings.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita L. is 43 years old. She is married to Elpidio, who is 51 years old, who maintains their small farming business. They were blessed with four children, namely: Joey, 25 years old, high school graduate; Reymund, 22 years old and still studying as a junior in high school; Dennis, 18 years old and studying as a sophomore in high school; and the youngest Elpher, 12 years old and currently in grade six.

Perlita manages, together with her husband, a chicken farm beside their house. Perlita wants to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP4,000 to start up a hog raising business which will be of great help to her family. According to her, due to financial difficulties, her village store was not maintained, and she wants to slowly bring back her lost business through the opportunity that the lenders give.

She is hoping for a better standard of living through the success of her pig raising business, said Perlita. She also added that living together with her happy family is important while facing every trial that will come along.

loans.use: To start a hog raising business

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn M. is a single parent who sells vegetables and cooked snacks in their village at San Lorenzo Ilagan, Isabela. Her child, Christian, serves as her inspiration in life. Her son is four years old and will go to a Day Care Center this next school year, thus, Rubelyn strives to earn money for her child. They are currently living with her parents in the village since her husband left her when she was barely four months pregnant with Christian.

Rubelyn is working for a better life because she wants to provide the best for her child. She maintains her business to provide a daily income and be able to save a little for the education of her child. However, due to lack of capital she was not able to generate higher sales. Because of this, Rubelyn decided to look for a lending program to assist her in the business for her to improve and increase her daily income. She wants to borrow PHP4,000 to fulfill her plans. She is working hard to attain her dream of having a successful business and she believes that through her faith with God, her dream will somehow become a reality because with God, “nothing is impossible.”

loans.use: Financial assistance to improve her business.

loans.name: Unidos Podemos 10 Group

texts.en:
Group 10 from the Unidos Podemos Bank of Hope is asking for their 2nd loan from Esperanza International. This group from El Seybo consists of men only.

Eusebio D. R. is their group coordinator. His small business consists of raising pigs. He has a nine-year-old child and is a single parent. He will use this loan to buy a few piglets, as well as vitamins, food, and serum to feed them and help them grow bigger. Some of the other group members also raise pigs, and others sell fruits or vegetables. Eusebio hopes his business will be profitable enough one day to allow him to repair his house. He works very hard and takes excellent care of the pigs he raises. He believes this loan will help him achieve his goal of making sure his family is healthy and living a good life.

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting this group of hard working men!

loans.use: Purchase pigs, food, and vitamins

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria A. has a small store in their village. She maintains her business to support her family's basic needs. The store is their sole source of family income, since her husband is only a part-time construction worker. Gloria is rigorously looking for other business opportunities aside from her store, to earn more money and uplift her family's life. Apart from her business, she also hopes to continue to send her children to school to finish their studies for a better future. Thus, Gloria wanted to borrow the amount of PHP8,000 to further develop her community store.  
	
“It feels good when someone appreciates your deeds,” said Gloria, and she promises herself that she will continuously work harder while still strong to support her family. She is 40 years old with three children, namely: Denmark - 20 years old, fourth year college; Cherry Mae - 14 years old, third year high school; and John – 6 years old, kindergarten. Her husband, Nelson, also tries his best to earn a living for their family.

loans.use: Store Improvement

loans.name: Amelyn

texts.en:
Amelyn V. lives in the village of Sitio Anguapan, Sto Nińo Tumauini, Isabela. She is 27 years old and is married to Oscar who is 10 years older than her. They have three children: Princess - 7 years old, grade one; Precious - 6 years old, kindergarten; and the youngest is Clarence - 3 months old. In the village, Amelyn strives for a better livelihood to help her husband earn their daily living and give their children a better education.  

Amelyn learned to manage a vending business in their village. She entered this business because she wants to help her husband to provide for their needs and uplift their poor living situation. She roams around the village selling her vegetable products. Sometimes, her husband also serves as part-time driver aside from being a helper. Amelyn is frightened of not being able to meet her family’s growing needs because of the unavailability of a stable source of livelihood. This is the reason why she is asking for a loan amounting to PHP4,000 as financial support for her business. She is hoping that her loan will be approved in order to buy different kinds of vegetables in bulk.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia O. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: three sons and one daughter. She says one of her children is at the Polytechnic, one is in senior high school, and the others are in junior high school. Felicia lives with the children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is an agricultural dominated town. It is about forty-five minutes drive from Sunyani, the regional capital. Her husband lives and farms in a nearby village.

Felicia has been trading in charcoal for eight years. She procures bags of charcoal from nearby villages and sells them in her community. Felicia wants a loan to increase her working capital, so she can procure more bags of charcoal. She hopes to help her husband give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: Procure bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Dakila

texts.en:
Dakila G. is a 39 year old vendor from the village of Sitio Anguapan of Sto. Nińo Tumauini, Isabela. She is married to Marcos, a construction worker and farmer at the same time. They are blessed with four children: the first child is Jay Mark – 16 years old, third year high school; John Carlo -13 years old first year high school; Marco Jerome – 10 years old grade five in the primary level; while the youngest child is Christian Eurey - 1 year old. Dakila supports her husband in supporting their basic needs at home and the educational needs of their children by working as a vendor. 

Dakila is a vegetable vendor in their village. She sells bananas and some other basic goods. She wishes to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP5,000 in order to improve her business. She wants to buy additional products and stock for her business. She is hoping for a better life and to achieve this, Dakila said that she must work hard to support her family. She is willing to do everything for the benefit of her children, and she wants them to earn a degree someday. However, financial difficulties hinder her from doing so.

loans.use: Business Improvement

loans.name: Perty

texts.en:
To become a successful businesswoman who lives a wonderful life is Perty's ambition. She is 38 years old and is still single. She can be best described as a hard working woman. She believes that hard work is the key towards the development and progress of every business. She is the breadwinner of her family, thus, is very ambitious to have a better life and earn money to support her parent’s medication.

Perty runs a sari-sari store (local term for a village store) business in the village. She is requesting a loan of PHP9,000 improve her business. With this amount, Perty hopes to increase her income to satisfy her family's basic needs and medication. She believes that the amount she requested will be of great help to her business and family.

loans.use: Business Development

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.es:
El señor Reynaldo vive en casa alquilada con su mamá en la calle Inca Roca de la zona de Tacahua de la ciudad de La Paz; Reynaldo trabaja en un taller pero al mismo tiempo trabaja individualmente reparando puertas y ventanas a domicilio. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de una maquina para soldar y de esta manera continuar con su trabajo individual y así poder cubrir sus necesidades de alimentación y otros.

Esta es la primera vez que solicita un crédito de Impro; la actividad que desarrolla lo califica para obtener un crédito.
texts.en:
Reynaldo lives in a rented house with his mother on Inca Roca Street in the Tacahua area of the city of La Paz. Reynaldo has a job in a workshop and also works individually repairing doors and windows in people's homes. He is soliciting this loan to buy a welding machine for his individual work, which will allow him to cover the costs of necessities such as food. This is his first loan from Impro; his developing business qualified him for the credit.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase welding machine for door and window repair business

loans.name: Ruben

texts.es:
El señor Ruben vive en casa de sus padres en la calle Luis Eguia de la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz, de profesión contador, tiene una oficina en la ciudad de El Alto lugar donde comparte un ambiente con su tío. El crédito que solicita es para comprar un escritorio e implementar mejor su oficina y de esta manera dar estabilidad a su negocio.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2005 y su historial de pagos es muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Ruben lives in his parents' house on Luis Eguia Street in the Alto San Pedro area of La Paz. He works as an accountant with an office in the city of El Alto, where he shares a room with his uncle. He will use this loan to buy a desk and make improvements to his office, thus giving more stability to his business. He has been an Impro client since 2005, and is eligible for more credit because of his excellent repayment history.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase desk for accounting office

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie P. is 36 years old, and married to Ferdinand who is a 38 year old farmer. They are blessed with four children, namely: Felmie - 15 years old, third year high school; Delenger - 13 years old, first year high school; and Kenneth - 9 years old and Fredick 8 years old, who are both elementary students. Lailanie loves her family very much and she keeps doing what is best for them, especially for her children. She hopes to send them to college for them to have a better future.  

Lailanie retail sells rice in their village of Sitio Anguapan. She wishes to receive a loan amounting to PHP3,000 to use as additional capital for her existing business to improve her rice vending. "Adding at least 100 kilos of rice will be of great help," said Lailanie. She is working hard to improve the business and be able to maintain it for a long period of time for her children’s education. The business is only 6 months old and she hopes that it will grow soon.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
With her motto in life, “try and try until you succeed”, Delia is more determined to do everything for the sake of her family. She is 40 years old and married to Gerson, a farmer.  Their three children are: Ren Ren - 19 years old, college undergraduate and now helping his father with the farm; May Ann - 16 years old, junior high school student; and Jerwin - 13 years old, freshman high school student. The family has a harmonious relationship and lives happily in Caliguian, Burgos, Isabela.

With her desire to send her children to school to finish their studies and provide them with a comfortable life, Delia decided to start a business to help them with their everyday living. Aside from the income they earn from farming, Delia has been engaged in hog raising for almost ten years and is able to generate a net income of PHP5,000 every four months. She budgets her income to support her children’s education and for some of their household expenses.  

She also plans to renovate and improve their pig pen. In order for her to achieve her plans, she is now requesting a loan of PHP5,000.00. She also plans to buy another piglet to increase her business.

loans.use: To buy a piglet and renovate the pigpen.

loans.name: Cristo Redentor 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
These ladies from Group 1 of Cristo Redentor Bank of Hope from San Pedro de Macoris are on their third loan cycle with Esperanza International. Francisca L. is their group coordinator. She is the mother of 5 children: ages 14, 12, 6, 3, and a 5-month-old baby. She has a beauty salon where she provides hair care for women. She will use this loan to purchase different kinds of hair products, including some high-quality hair product lines that she can charge a higher rate per service. Because she does all the salon work herself, Francisca has very little time to spend with her children. Luckily, her salon is in her own house. She dreams of providing a safe home for her children to live in and making her hair salon a modern facility where she can provide all kinds of beauty services. 

Juana V. is the Group 2 coordinator. They are on their second loan cycle with Esperanza International. Juana has two different businesses: selling clothes and selling gasoline. She sells the clothes in her home, and she sells the gasoline on the road close to her house. The community roads are often small and it's hard to find gas stations, so it's easy for her to sell small quantities to the motorcycle drivers. She hopes to expand both businesses in order to provide a better quality of life for her family. 

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: To buy hair products

loans.name: Ednalyn

texts.en:
Ednalyn Cardona lives in the village of Sitio Anguapan of Barangay Sto. Nińo Tumauini, Isabela. Ednalyn is 35 years old, and married to Raul Cardona, 32 years old, a simple rice and corn farmer. They are blessed with two children, namely: Rachelle Ann - 13 years old, second year high school; and Raul C. Jr. - 9 years old, grade four. Their family is happily living in the village aiming for a better living in the future. 

Ednalyn manages a small store business in their sitio (small village). She has been operating her business for three years through God’s grace, said Ednalyn. Her dream to improve her store into a bigger one to satisfy her customers’ demands pushed her to get a loan amounting to PHP4,000 to purchase additional products for the store in bulk. Her eagerness to improve her store motivates her to work harder to meet her goal and to attain her dream to have a better living someday.

loans.use: To purchase additional products.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty A. is 32 years old. She is married and has three children -- a girl and two boys. Two of her children are currently in the primary school. The last born, however, is yet to start school. She says her husband has travelled abroad for greener pastures. She lives with the children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is an agricultural-dominated town. It is about a 45 minute drive from Sunyani, the regional capital. Gifty sells eggs to make some income to provide for the family. She procures the eggs from the poultry farms in the surrounding villages, and then sells them in a store at the local market square. She sells mostly to retailers. Gifty says she has been in this business for six years. She wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure more eggs. She hopes to improve upon the standard of living of the family and give the children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure eggs

loans.name: Maria Eugenia

texts.es:
La señora Maria Eugenia vive en alquiler con su mamá en la calle Manuel Jofre de la zona de Tacahua de la ciudad de La Paz. La actividad que ella realiza es la elaboración de donuts, las mismas que ella comercializa llevando a los diferentes colegios, con esta actividad ella puede cubrir sus mas mínimas necesidades. El crédito que solicita es para compra de insumos (harina, queso, levadura, sal, etc.) y poder elaborar empanadas y otras masitas de esta manera  mejorar sus ingresos y estabilizar su negocio.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2007  y su historial de pagos es muy bueno; también fue parte de Kiva con dos créditos anteriores. Por la actividad que realiza y el carácter social puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Maria Eugenia lives in a rented house with her mother on Manuel Jofre Street in the Tacahua area of La Paz. She makes donuts and sells them at various schools, enabling her to cover her basic expenses. This loan will be used to purchase inputs (flour, cheese, yeast, salt, etc.) so she will be able to make empanadas and cookies to improve her income and stabilize her business. She has been an Impro client since 2007 and has a good repayment history. She has also borrowed through Kiva twice. Her business and her character have given her access to more credit.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, cheese, yeast and other inputs for making and selling empanadas, cookies and donuts

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes was a simple housewife before she entered into selling firewood. Her husband, Apolonio, works as a farmer and he used to help her in the business that she initiated. She is 49 years old. They are blessed with nine children, namely: Lorelyn - 28 years old, graduated with BS Elementary Education, now a public school teacher; Vivian - 25 years old, high school graduate, now works as OFW in Taiwan; Jerimar - 24 years old, elementary school graduate; Judy - 22 years old, undergraduate of computer programming, also works in Taiwan; Dennis - 20 years old, high school graduate; Irene - 14 years old, second year high school; Aries - 11 years old and Jasper - 9 years old, both studying in the elementary grades; and Clarissa the youngest is 4 years old.

Her new business of wholesaling firewood created an alternative source of income for Lourdes' family. She collects wood from the little forest located in their village. To further improve her existing business, Lourdes wants to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP5,000 that will enable her to pay young people to help her collect wood for her business. She hopes that her current business will pave the way to achieving all her ambitions for her family, especially a better future for her children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Noli

texts.en: Noli is a resident of Calamagui 1st village. He and his wife Lority are both 28 years old. They have a son named Daniel who is now two years old. Noli operates a tricycle transport business in their village, a livelihood activity where he generates income to support his family's needs. So his motorcycle will not become damaged beyond repair, Noli wanted to request a loan amounting to PHP6,000 for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle. He believes that hard work is the key to progress, thus he strives a lot.

loans.use: Motorcyle Repair and Maintenance

loans.name: Santa Catalina De Sillacancha Group

texts.es:
Este banquito responde al nombre de "Santa Catalina de Sillacancha"; lleva el nombre de una santa patrona de la comunidad de Sillacancha en el poblado de Calca, de la provincia del Cusco, ubicado a 1hora y 30 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco, es parte integrante del valle sagrado de los inkas.

Este banco está conformado por 07 mujeres y 05 varones, quienes se dedican principalmente a la agricultura, está zona posee un clima cálido y fértil; en la que se cultiva entre los productos de maíz, papa, hortalizas, y otros, diversidad de frutas, las socias del banco invertirán el préstamo otorgado en la compra de fertilizantes y compra de productos como las semillas para la nueva temporada de sembrío, previo al trabajo de tierras para poder ser cultivadas nuevamente; muchas de ellas son también comerciantes, llevan sus verduras y frutas a diferentes lugares de la región, también elaboran riquísimas mermeladas de pulpa de frutas, sin utilizar conservantes, son productos 100% naturales.

Las socias valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado, ya que en estás zonas rurales, no se adquiere a la banca financiera de forma menos compleja; por lo tanto ellos se comprometen  a la devolución del mismo en el plazo estipulado y reiteran su apoyo a estos socios con deseos de superación.
texts.en:
This small bank is called "Santa Catalina de Sillacancha" after one of the patron saints of the community of Sillacancha in the village of Calca, Cusco province, located 1 hour and 30 minutes from the city of Cusco. This community is in the sacred valley of the Inkas. This bank is made up of seven women and five men who are mainly farmers. This area has a hot climate and is fertile, where the main crops are corn, potato, vegetables and such, as well as a variety of fruit. The members of the bank will invest the loan in the purchase of fertilizers and products such as seeds for the new sowing season, before working the soil so the fields can be resown. Many of them are also merchants: they bring their fruits and vegetables to different places in the region as well as making delicious marmelades from their fruit, without the use of preservatives. They make 100% natural products. The members value and are grateful for the loan: because they are in the countryside they do not have access to traditional banks. They are committed to repaying the loan on schedule and have pledged their support to the members who want to progress.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, products, to make marmelades.

loans.name: Fuente De Bendicion 1&2 Group

texts.en:
The Fuente de Bendicion Bank of Hope from San Pedro de Macoris is starting their entrepreneurship with their first loan from Esperanza International. Joselania S. and Maria G. are the two group coordinators. Joselania is the mother of 5 children between the ages of 16 and 7, and Maria has a 6-year-old son. Joselania has a clothing sales business, and Maria has a vegetable stand. Both will use their loans to buy new products for their customers. They find their daily work is their biggest challenge, but they also believe having their own businesses will allow them to take better care of their children by being self-employed and generating income to provide for their needs. When asked about their dreams for the future, Joselania answered she would like to own a large boutique. Maria want to have her own grocery store and a house of her own. 
Please support these entrepreneurs as they start their businesses thanks to this loan. 
Thank you!

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Clara sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs.She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N120,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is 47 years old and married with 8 children. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is 42 years old and married with 8 children. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica A. is 32 years old. Currently, Monica is single and is hopeing to get married soon. She trades to make some income to help herself and her younger siblings who are dependent on her. She lives with two younger siblings in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is an agricultural-dominated town. It is about a 45 minute drive from Sunyani, the regional capital. She says one of her siblings is in the university while the other is in the senior high school. Monica trades in gari and smoked fish. Gari is a local delicacy produced from cassava dough. It can be eaten raw with sugar and roasted groundnut or with cooked beans and oil. She procures bags of gari and the smoked fish all the way from Techiman where she claims the price is less expensive. Monica treks to other markets to sell her goods. She sells mostly to food vendors. She has been in business for three years. Monica wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure bags of gari and smoked fish in bulk.

loans.use: To procure gari and smoked fish

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa O. is 50 years old and married with 6 children. She lives in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose O. lives in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. She is 51 years old and married with 5 children. She sells drinks and cooked foods. She needs the loan amount of N130,000 to purchase one deep freezer to enable her to sell cold drinks to her customers. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase one deep freezer

loans.name: Dios Es Amor 6 Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs belongs to the Dios es Amor (God is Love) Bank of Hope in San Pedro de Macoris. They are starting their businesses with this first loan. Lucia is the group coordinator and she sells clothes. She has 5 children; the oldest is 10 years old and the youngest is just two months old. She will use the entire amount of her loan to purchase clothes to sell in her business. She finds her biggest challenge in life is to be there for her children as a parent, and not merely as a provider. She knows her presence and guidance are important, which is why she hopes that (and works hard for) her business to grow so she can be self-sufficient and spend more time with her young children.

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting these new entrepreneurs!

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence lives in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. She is 35 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica lives in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. She is 43 years old and married with 5 children. She sells foodstuffs and drinks. She needs the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase drinks to sell and a refrigerator. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase drinks to sell and a refrigerator

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 29 years old and married without a child. She is a hair stylist and she also sells hair cream and hair extensions. She needs a loan of N70,000 to purchase more hair cream and hair extensions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair cream and hair extension to sell

loans.name: Dios Es Amor 7 Group

texts.en:
Group 7 from the Dios es Amor Bank of Hope is starting their first loan cycle with Esperanza International. Most of these ladies did not have a formal business before. They will be able to have a more organized income-generating activity thanks to this loan. 
Dorkas C. is the group coordinator. She is a young mother with three children ages 8, 5, and 3 months,  Dorkas buys appliances at her customers' request and delivers them to their homes. She usually comes to the Capital to buy the appliances. 
Dorkas dreams of having her own Internet cafe. She thinks it's a great business that has guaranteed clientele thanks to school and college students who would use the internet for research. She also thinks a business like this would allow her to spend more time with her young children and not travel so much for work. She also hopes to make enough profit to be able to go to college. She thinks a better education would allow her to improve her business in a smarter way. 
Please support the initiative of these young women. Thank you!

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Marlon Antonio

texts.es: El Sr. Marlon vende juntos con su mama granos básicos, productos de cosméticos y refrescos, el tiene 24 años de edad, reside en el barrio el pilar en la ciudad de Managua, el vende desde que tiene 15 años ayudaba a sus padres y inicio con ayuda de su mama, para obtener sus propios ingresos, y poder mantener a su familia ya que su esposa le tiene dos hijo uno de 4años y el otro de un mes de nacido. Sus planes para su familia es fortalecer la unión, y poder dar buenos valores a sus hijos. Con esta solicitud de crédito es para incrementar el volumen de mercadería variada  para ofertar a sus clientes, a si como atraer a más clientes para tener una estructura sólida con el negocio. Que afuturo beneficie a su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Marlon sells basic grains. cosmetics and soft drinks with his mom. He is 24 years old and lives in the Pilar district of the city of Managua. He has been selling since he was 15 years old. He helps his parents and his mom helped him when he was starting out so he could earn his own income and be able to provide for his family. His wife has two children: a four-year-old and a one-month-old. His plans for his family are to strengthen their unity and to be able to raise his children with good values. This loan is to increase the volume and assortment of merchandise to offer to his customers, which will attract more customers and let him have a solid basis for his business. This will benefit his family in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic grains, cosmetics and other prodcuts to build up inventory.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is 45 years old. She is married with six children - two boys and four girls. One child is in junior high school and two are in primary school. The oldest three children have completed school and are working for a while to earn some money. Akua’s husband is a repairer. He sews and mends bags in the community market square. The family lives in a rented apartment in Dormaa Ahenkro, a town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. An agricultural town, Dormaa Ahenkro is about a 45 minute drive from Sunyani, the regional capital.

Akua trades in fresh yams, plantains and other foodstuffs to support her husband financially. She procures her goods from nearby villages. She sells the yams and goods on a tabletop in the market square to retailers and other customers. She has been in business for five years. Akua wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure foodstuffs in bulk. She hopes to help her husband improve their standard of living and give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To procure yams and other foodstuffs

loans.name: Vida Group

texts.en:
Vida is a large group of 20 borrowers who are all trying to receive their second loan. With the first loan this group received they were all able to get their small businesses off the ground and start making some money. This second loan will help each individual grow their business and, hopefully, start increasing their earnings!

Sira M. is the representative of this group. She is an extremely hard working woman and she has to be because she has 4 young children she must take care of. Each child is under the age of 14 and requires a lot of attention and care. Before Sira's first loan she had almost no form of income and found it very difficult to even feed all her young children. With the first loan she started a very small cafeteria. She hopes to use this next loan to add a wider range of products to sell. She is very excited about her cafeteria and finally feels like she is going to be able to support her children and give them a better life. She is excited to finally have something of her own and she knows she will be a success someday!

Thanks for all your support!!

loans.use: Buy products for her cafeteria

loans.name: Marbell Petrona

texts.es: La joven Marbel tiene 24 años de edad, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la ciudad de Managua, tiene una niña de 2 años y su esposo  trabaja en un restaurante en servicios de vigilancia. El negocio es la venta de ropa, y productos de cosmético que vende al contado y al crédito que inicio desde hace  cuatro años con fondos propios,  con la iniciativa de prosperar para su desarrollo personal. Con esta solicitud de crédito  es la segunda en la que va invertir en comprar materiales de construcción para hacer un cuarto y tener mas espacio. Sus planes es poder aumentar el volumen de venta y obtener mejores ingresos que gracias a Afodenic se están haciendo realidad.
texts.en:
This young woman is Marbell. She is 24 years old and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighbourhood of Managua. She has a two-year-old daughter and her husband works for a restaurant providing security. She sells clothing and cosmetics both on account and for cash. She started her business four years ago with her own money, wanting to improve her situation and for her personal development. She is asking for this, her second loan, to buy construction materials to build a room and have more space. Her goal is to increase her sales volume and make more money, a goal which thanks to Afodenic is becoming reality.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a room

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence sells provisions and foodstuffs. She hopes to expand this business. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N70,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is married and has six children. Two of Akua's children are in junior high school. She lives with her family at Wasa Simpa, a suburb of Tarkwa in the western region of Ghana. She is 50 years old. Her husband is a farmer who harvests maize. For the past 4 years, Akua has run a shop where she sells items like women's rubber slippers and bags of rice. Through Akua's unique customer care and bookkeeping management she has attracted many customers who buy from her stand. Sometimes she sells her items door to door ("hawking"). 

Akua belongs to a village bank called "Joy." Akua is constrained by funds for running her business. She hopes to receive GH¢500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. The loan will help her upgrade her inventory by purchasing good quality and in more quantity. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She will be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To purchase rubber slippers and bags of rice.

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She hopes to expand this business. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N120,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.es:
La señora Nicolasa P. Coronel vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Llojeta, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo, el señor Pedro Huanca y su hijo.
La señora Nicolasa así como su esposo trabajan como empleados en una ladrillería en la misma zona.
Con créditos anteriores construyeron dos habitaciones en su vivienda, las que en la actualidad están ocupando.
El crédito es para la conclusión de la construcción en obra gruesa de dos habitaciones nuevas.
Esta es la novena vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Nicolasa P. Coronel lives in her own home with her husband, Pedro Huanca, and her son in the community of Llojeta, on the western slope of the city of La Paz. Nicolasa and her husband are employed by a brickworks factory in the community. Using previous loans, they have built two rooms which they currently live in, in their home. This loan will be used to finish the structural work of two new rooms. This is her ninth loan; our socio-economic analysis determined that she qualifies for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To begin the structural work for two new rooms for her home.

loans.name: Afua

texts.en:
Afua D. is 65 years old. She is widowed and the mother of seven children but currently all her children are fully independent. Afua has 8 grandchildren and she takes care of four of them. Her husband died through a prolonged sickness about 9 years ago. She has been very supportive in keeping their home through her current business. She lives with her grandchildren and her youngest child in a rented apartment in a town called Wasa Simpa in the western region of Ghana.

Afua has traded in coconut oil for 25 years. Coconut oil is produced from coconut fruits. She produces the oil and supplies it to food vendors to prepare their meals. She even treks to the villages to purchase the finished goods elsewhere when demand is very high.

Afua belongs to a village bank called "Joy." She hopes to receive GH¢400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of coconut and an electric milling machine to increase her efficiency and produce larger quantities. She believes the loan will help expand her business to raise more income to support and to provide food for her family and finance an education for her youngest child and her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy more bags of coconuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: Doña Maria es una mujer que trabaja  en la venta de zapatos, ropa y cosméticos desde hace catorce años el cual inicio con fondos propios para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Tiene 42 años de edad, reside en el barrio memorial sandino en la ciudad de Managua, sus hijos son mayores y viven independientes, su esposo es inspector de la policía nacional. Con este crédito es su noveno ciclo el cual va invertir en mercadería variada de ropa de niño como para adulto, zapatos. Estos préstamos han sido de muchos beneficios en su vida personal por que se siente que ha logrado sus objetivos en el comercio. A corto plazo espera incrementar el volumen de inventario.
texts.en:
Maria is a woman who works selling shoes, clothing and cosmetics, beginning 14 years ago with her own funds in order to help her husband with household expenses. She is 42 years old and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood of Managua. Her children are grown and live independently, and her husband is an inspector with the national police. This is her ninth loan cycle, which she will invest in merchandise including clothing for children and adults as well as shoes. These loans have been very beneficial to her personal life, as she feels she has accomplished her commercial goals. In the short term, she hopes to increase her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and shoes

loans.name: Mujeres Decididas 1 Group

texts.en: Mujeres Decididas 1 is a group of 5 borrowers all trying to receive their first loan with Esperanza International. Each member is hoping to take out a small loan and start their very own small business. Lucy A. is the representative of this group, and a great leader with the group. Lucy is the mother of 2 very young children and knows that this is her chance to provide them with a better life. She always dreamed of providing her children with a good education. Right now Lucy is having a hard time feeding both children and does not have a steady income. She is hoping to start a small store selling all sorts of goods. She feels like she is ready to start something of her own and start making her own money. She is very excited about this opportunity and is going to make the most of it!  Thanks for all your support!!

loans.use: Buy products for small store

loans.name: Tomasa Esperanza

texts.es: Doña Tomasa tiene 60 años de edad, reside en el  Barrio 380 en la ciudad de Managua, sus hijos son independientes, la Sra. Tomasa trabaja de conserje desde hace nueve años, sus metas es poder terminar de hacer las mejoras a su vivienda que gracias a los prestamos de Afodenic ha logrado poder mejorar su casa con esta solicitud es la octava la cual va invertir en comprar materiales de construcción para terminar de hacer un muro en la parte de enfrente para tener mas seguridad de la delincuencia. Y poder gozar de sus esfuerzos.
texts.en:
Tomasa is 60 years old and lives in Barrio 380 in the city of Managua. Her children are independent. Tomasa has worked as a concierge for nine years. Her goal is to be able to finish her home improvements, which she has been able to start thanks to Afodenic loans. With this, her eighth loan, she will invest in the purchase of construction materials to finish building a front wall to increase security against vandalism, and thus be able to enjoy her efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a wall

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es: Filomena es pequeña productora de Nueva Guinea, está solicitando el 5to crédito a la institución de AFODENIC con el objetivo de comprar 5 ternero desarrollo y de esta forma aumentar el inventario del hato gandero, obtiene ingresos de la venta de leche y comercialización de ganado, es una mujer emprendedora, responsable, honesta a demostrado  buena conducta y moral crediticia ante la institución, doña Filomena  trabaja en las actividades de la finca con su hijo, ella está satisfecha con el apoyo recibido de AFODENIC, de esta forma ha salido adelante en el desarrollo de la actividad ganadera y ha mejorado las condiciones de vida del núcleo familiar.
texts.en:
Filomena is a small producer from Nueva Guinea. She is seeking her fifth loan from Afodenic to buy five growing calfs and thereby increase her cattle herd. She earns her income selling milk and livestock. She is an enterprising woman, responsible and honest, and she has demonstrated good conduct and morality to the institution. Filomena works her farm with her son. She is satisfied with the support she has received from Afodenic; she has been able to move ahead with her livestock activities and improve living conditions for her nuclear family.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock to raise

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah C. is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. Currently all her children have completed junior high school. She has multiple businesses. She lives with her husband,a professional tailor, who sews all kinds of dresses.

Hannah owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk etc. In addition she also sells linen for sewing, charcoal, tomatoes etc in the community market.

She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. With her ten years trading experience she wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve sales to enable her to save more for her children's education. Hannah belongs to the village bank called ‘Adom Akyede’ meaning the Gift of Grace. She would be grateful for the assistance. She hopes to receive GH¢500 to restock her inventory.

loans.use: To restock her inventory

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa K. is 46 years old. She is divorced and has four children who are dependent on her. Two of her children are male and two female. She says one of her children is in junior high school and two are in senior high school. The first born is currently learning a trade – hair dressing. According to Adwoa, infidelity on the part of her husband caused the break up. She says, however, that he helps to care for the children. Adwoa lives with the children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is an agriculture-dominated town. It is about 45 minute drive from Sunyani, the regional capital.

Adwoa trades in fresh yams to make some income to provide for the children. She buys tubers of yams from Kintampo which she sells in the market square to retailers and other customers. She has been in business for 20 years. Adwoa wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can buy tubers of yams in bulk. She hopes to help her children have access to a good education.

loans.use: To buy tubers of yams in bulk

loans.name: Mujeres Decididas 2 Group

texts.en:
Mujeres Decididas 2 is a group of five people who are all trying to receive their first loans with Esperanza International. This group comes from an extremely poor area in San Pedro, Dominican Republic. The majority of this group do not have a steady income, and they are looking to start small businesses to change that fact. This group is very excited about this opportunity, and they are ready to get started on their businesses.

Alexandra G. is the representative of this group. She is planning on starting a small store where she will sell all sorts of goods. She is the mother of two young children, and she wants nothing more than to be able to provide them with a comfortable life. She dreams of sending them to a University someday. Alexandra is an extremely hard worker who will find a way to make her business work. She is excited to finally be getting a chance, and she admits that opportunities like this haven't come often in her life. She is ready to take this next step towards a better life!!

Thank you!

loans.use: Buy products for her store

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana M. is 42 years old. She is married and has six children. Currently three are in school while the remaining three have completed junior high school. Her husband works with a rubber manufacturing company. The family lives together in a rented apartment in the community.

Diana loves selling goods, the business through which she earns a living.  She has been selling yams for four years to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy yams from the farmers. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy yams in bulk. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school. Diana belongs to the village bank called ‘Adom Akyede’ meaning the Gift of Grace. She is grateful for your assistance. She hopes to receive GHS800 to restock her inventory.

loans.use: To buy yams

loans.name: Sanobar

texts.ru: Халимова Санобар продолжает сотрудничать с Микроинвест. В прошлый раз она получив займ получила хорошую прибыль. Ее муж продолжает работать в России и присылает деньги для содержания своей семьи, но в связи с финансовым кризисом денег он присылает меньше обычного. Поэтому занятие предпринимательством Санобар актуально и приносит дополнительный доход для содержания семьи. Сейчас Санобар хочет получить новый займ и прикупить весенний ассортимент детской обуви. Новый займ собирается погасить в течении месяца.
texts.en:
Sanobar H. continues her partnership with MicroInvest. Thanks to the last loan, she was able to make a good profit. Sanobar’s husband works in Russia and sends money to support the family, however, due to the financial crisis, he sends less money than usual. This is why Sanobar’s entrepreneurial activity is practical; after all, it brings supplemental income needed to support her family. Currently, Sanobar wants to obtain a new loan in order to purchase spring assortment of children’s shoes. She plans to repay this loan within one month.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spring assortment of children's shoes

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana K. is 30 years old, divorced, and the mother of four children. She lives with her children who are in school. She got divorced due to pressure from the husband's parent. In spite of the challenges she faces, Susana believes in hand work and dedication, which are the secret of her success. She owns and operates a local restaurant where she sells local foods like banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains, and it is eaten with hot pepper or soup. She also sells ice water in a sachet form attached to her food joint. Susana realized automatically that after eating, people would need water to quench their thirst. 

Susana needs a loan to enable her to purchase more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She says the cost of raw materials is very high now. She also wants to save part of the loan to venture into crop farming in the near future. Susana belongs to the village bank called ‘Adom Akyede’ meaning the Gift of Grace. She is grateful for your assistance. She hopes to receive GHS1000 to restock her inventory. Susana has been in business for five years now.

loans.use: To buy maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood

loans.name: Murod

texts.ru: Бадалов Мурод парень 32 лет, женат и воспитывает 3 детей. Мурод не имеет постоянной работы и подрабатывает на строительстве частных домов. Он является основным добытчиком семьи. Кроме своего основного занятия Мурод также занимается куплей продажей мелкого рогатого скота на местных рынках. Узнав про КИВА и изучив его условия Мурод решил подать заявку на получение займа. Это его первый опыт в кредитовании и на полученный займ он собирается увеличить свой оборотный капитал. Полученный займ собирается погасить в течении 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Murod B. is 32 years old, married and has three children. He does not have a permanent job and works part-time doing home construction. He is the sole provider for his family. Besides his primary work, Murod has a business of buying and selling livestock at local markets. Having found out about Kiva and its lending terms, Murod decided to request a loan. This is his first experience with obtaining a credit. He plans to use this loan to increase his working capital. He will repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Mujeres Hacia El Futuro Group

texts.en:
Mujeres Hacia el Futuro is a large group of 20 women hoping to receive loans. This group is very mixed in that some members will be receiving their third loan, while other are on their seventh loan. The one thing they all have in common is that they are in the process of improving their lives. Many of the group members have already doubled or tripled their income, and they hope to continue raising their standard of living.
